greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Reversed rows of A178252 presented as diagonals of an irregular triangle.
comment: The diagonals of T are the reversed rows of A178252. E.g., the fifth diagonal of T is (1,2,2,1,1) from the example below, which is the fifth reversed row of A178252.

Factoring out the greatest common divisor (gcd) of the coefficients of the sub-polynomials in the indeterminate q of the polynomials in s presented on p. 12 of the Alexeev et al. link and then evaluating the sub-polynomials at q=1 gives the first nine rows of T given in the example below. E.g., for k=6 (the seventh row), q*s^6 + (6*q + 9*q^2) s^4 + (15*q + 15*q^2) s^2 + 5  = q*s^6 + 3*(2*q + 3*q^2)*s^4 + 15*(q + q^2)*s^2 + 5 generates (1,2+3,1+1,1)=(1,5,2,1).
The row length sequence of this irregular triangle is A008619(n) = 1 + floor(n/2). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Aug 25 2015
link: N. Alexeev, J. Andersen, R. Penner, P. Zograf, Enumeration of chord diagrams on many intervals and their non-orientable analogs, arXiv:1307.0967 [math.CO], 2013-2014.
mathematica: max = 15; coes = Table[ PadRight[ CoefficientList[ BernoulliB[n, x], x], max], {n, 0, max-1}]; inv = Inverse[coes] // Numerator; t[n_, k_] := inv[[n, k]]; t[n_, k_] /; k == n+1 = 1; Table[t[n-k+1, k], {n, 2, max+1}, {k, 2, Floor[n/2]+1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 22 2015 *)
results.author: _Tom Copeland_, Jun 18 2015
